intro: Potamogeton crispus f. gemmifer, commonly known as the hairy pondweed, is a variant of the common pondweed characterized by its distinctive, finely serrated leaves and the presence of gemmae, which are small, vegetative propagules. It is an aquatic plant native to freshwater environments across Europe, Asia, and North America. The plant typically grows in shallow water, forming dense mats that can dominate aquatic vegetation. Its leaves are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a rough texture, and it produces small, greenish flowers that are pollinated by wind. This species plays a role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat for invertebrates and serving as a food source for herbivorous fish.
